content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Normally I show 8 by showing 8 fingers, I never realized that I then in fact am showing 23. Creative clash!
thumb / thumb index middle ring out of thumb / thumb index middle ring.

Very nice idea. I do think at this moment the test vs validator cases are a bit unbalanced. For example, test 1 with 7 is quite different from validator 1 with 28. My guess would be that for this clash test/validator case matching simply comes down to having close numbers (eg 7/6, 1/2, 28/27, 33/32 as test/validators).

Also, I first tried it 'reverse', and the case 0 was very clarifying for me - but that one is hidden away as validator. 0 (fist fist) as testcase instead of validator might be very helpful for reverse players.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a nice puzzle. And the fact that we have to list all fingers or output 'fist' is the twist that make it a little bit harder than just converting an int from base 10 to base 6.

Downside: It is possible to hard code the solution, but for a clash of code I think it is fine

It is a nice idea, changing the base of a number with a little extra.
But what about the cases where no finger has to be shown on one hand ? Like 0 to 6 and all the multiple of 6 ?

It might be nice to add "none" or "fist" as possible output and integrate it in the test case. (It will also help for the reverse mode)

Goal section
* Suggest to format "thumb", "index", "middle", "ring" and "little" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

Thanks.

hello :)

I was so frustated to find it was impossible to output an empty line, I didn't have the idea to "invent" the 0 in hand radix. It looks so obvious now you wrote it.

Thank you so much for your idea. I updated the statement, the tests and the solution :)

Thank you for your feedback :)

I remixed the tests/validators to have close numbers, and put 0 in the first tests.

Dumb question : how did you test the 'reverse' mode ? I can't find where to test it in the editor ^^'

Not a dumb question at all - sadly there is no reverse mode testing option. Whenever I see reverse mode is one of the contribution modes, I first try to only check the test cases without reading the statement; in the IDE test cases are not available so I have to make do with the contribution page.

It is not a perfect reverse test, because I can also see the validator cases. That is how I realized that the zero case was quite useful for solving this puzzle.

I hope Codingame will implement a reverse option for contribution testing.
